conversations.content: What was Berkshire Hathaway's gain in net worth during 1984, and how does it compare to your historical performance?

Our gain in net worth during 1984 was $152.6 million, or $133 per share. While this sounds good on the surface, I consider it mediocre compared to our historical 22.1% twenty-year compounded annual gain in book value. The 1984 gain was only 13.6%, which is a significant drop from our long-term average.
You mentioned that to earn 15% annually over the next decade, Berkshire Hathaway would need profits aggregating about $3.9 billion. What kind of ideas do you think are necessary to achieve this goal?

To accomplish this, we would need a few big ideas - small ones just won't do. Unfortunately, Charlie Munger and I don't have any such ideas at present, but our experience has been that they do pop up occasionally. As I said, that's about as much of a strategic plan as we have right now!
What message do you think a company sends to its shareholders when it makes repurchases while its market value is below its business value?

When a company buys back its shares at a price below its true business value, it's like a big neon sign saying, 'Hey, we're looking out for you, shareholders!' It shows that management is focused on increasing the wealth of owners, not just expanding their own empire. And that, in turn, can boost shareholders' confidence and lead to more realistic market prices.
Can you give an example of how share repurchases have benefited your investments?

I can give you a few examples, actually. We've done very well with the large share repurchases of companies like GEICO, Washington Post, and General Foods - which happen to be three of our largest holdings. Those repurchases have worked out beautifully for us and for other shareholders, and they're a big part of why we've prospered over time.
What was Levitz Furniture's gross margin in its fiscal year 1984?
Levitz Furniture's gross margin in fiscal 1984 was 44.4%. To put that into perspective, for every $100 they sold something for, it only cost them $55.60 to buy it.
How do the Blumkins' secrets to their business success relate to their area of special competence?

The Blumkins define their area of special competence with extraordinary realism and act decisively on matters within it, but they also ignore propositions that fall outside of it. This focus is key to their success, and it's not about being flashy or chasing every opportunity - it's about knowing what you're good at and sticking to it.
What are the key characteristics that you look for in a family business, such as the Blumkin family?

I look for four main things: enthusiasm and energy, a clear definition of their area of special competence, the discipline to ignore enticing propositions outside of that area, and a commitment to behaving in a high-grade manner with everyone they deal with. As my partner Mrs. B puts it, 'sell cheap and tell the truth'.
What was unusual about the purchase of NFM, and what does it say about the Blumkin family's integrity?

What was unusual was that we didn't do any of the usual due diligence - no audit, no inventory check, no verification of receivables. We simply gave Mrs. B a check for $55 million, and she gave us her word. That's a testament to the trust we had in her and her family's integrity, and it's a deal that's worked out very well for us.
Do the economics of a dominant newspaper depend on the quality of the product it delivers?

No, the economics of a dominant newspaper are not directly tied to the quality of the product. In fact, I've seen third-rate papers making profits just as good as, or even better than, first-class ones, as long as they're dominant in their community. It's the dominance that matters, not necessarily the quality.
How do you ensure that the newspaper maintains high standards, given that the marketplace doesn't impose them?

Well, since the marketplace won't push us to be better, we have to push ourselves. That's why we've committed to spending more than average on news, and why I have confidence in our team, like Stan Lipsey and Murray Light, to apply high qualitative standards. It's up to management to set and maintain those standards.
What changes have you seen in the insurance market that have allowed you to raise prices, and how has your company's financial strength played a role in this?

Well, with the competition shaken due to poorer-than-average results in certain lines, we've been able to raise prices significantly in the last half of 1984 without losing much business. Our premier financial strength has made a real difference here - it's a promise that we can keep, even in adversity, and that's what buyers of insurance should be looking for.
How do you think your company's financial strength will impact its position in the market, particularly in areas like structured settlements and loss reserve assumptions?

I believe our financial strength is a particular asset in those areas. We're willing and able to keep our promises, even in a prolonged combination of depressed financial markets and unfavorable underwriting results. Not many other companies can say that, and I think that sets us apart, especially in businesses like structured settlements and loss reserve assumptions where stability and reliability are key.
What is more important to you when evaluating the performance of GEICO, business performance or market performance?

I can tell you straight out, it's business performance. We look at how the company is doing in terms of its core operations, not just how the market is valuing it at any given time. If the business is strong, the market will eventually catch on.
What qualities make Lou Simpson an effective investor for GEICO's funds?

Lou has a rare combination of temperamental and intellectual characteristics that make him an outstanding long-term investor. He operates with below-average risk and has consistently delivered returns that are the best in the insurance industry.
What components make up the loss expense charged in a property/casualty company's current income statement?

The loss expense charged in our current income statement includes four key components: losses that occurred and were paid during the year, estimates for losses that occurred and were reported but haven't been settled yet, estimates of the ultimate costs for losses that occurred during the year but we're not yet aware of, and the net effect of revisions to similar estimates made in past years.
Can you provide an example of how revisions to loss estimates can affect earnings in later years?

Let me give you an example. Suppose we had a claim from 1979 that we initially thought would settle for $10,000. We'd charge that to our earnings statement for 1979 and set up a liability reserve for the same amount. But if the claim actually settled in 1984 for $100,000, we'd have to charge an additional $90,000 to earnings in 1984, even though the expense really belonged to 1979. That's how revisions can misstate earnings in the year of correction.
How do insolvent insurance companies manage to stay afloat despite being broke?

Well, it's quite simple really. In the insurance business, cash comes in upfront when a policy is sold, but the losses are paid out much later. This means an insolvent insurer can appear flush with cash even when they're actually broke, because they're collecting premiums now and won't have to pay out claims until later. It's a bit like living off a credit card - you can look wealthy for a while, but eventually, the bill comes due.
What's the impact on Berkshire when other insurance companies become insolvent?

When those 'walking dead' insurance companies finally go under, we feel the pain in two ways. First, we have to compete with them while they're still operating, and they're willing to sell policies at any price just to keep the cash coming in. That makes it tough for us to compete. And second, when they do go bust, we end up paying a portion of their asset deficiencies through state guarantee funds. It's like being asked to help clean up someone else's mess - not exactly what we signed up for.
What was the basis for your decision to purchase WPPSS bonds despite the problems associated with them?

We judged the risks at the time of purchase to be more than compensated for by the prospects of profit, given the prices we paid - which were much lower than the current prices. It's a bit like buying a good business at a discount; if you can get it cheap enough, the potential for gain outweighs the risks.
How do you approach buying marketable stocks for Berkshire's insurance companies?

We use a business-valuation approach, where we consider what it would be like to buy the entire business. If we can buy small pieces of a business with good underlying economics at a fraction of its total worth, we figure something good is likely to happen. It's not a common approach, but it's worked for us.
You mention that most businesses have a limited upside potential unless more capital is continuously invested in them. Can you explain why this is the case, even under inflationary conditions?

Well, I think it's because most businesses just can't significantly improve their average returns on equity, no matter what the economic conditions are. It's not like inflation automatically makes your business more profitable. Now, if you're reinvesting your earnings, that's a different story. But on its own, inflation doesn't magically raise returns.
You use the example of a 30-year, zero-coupon, 12% bond and a $10 million business that earns 12% on equity. How do the growth prospects of these two investments compare?

They're actually pretty similar. If you take that bond and use the coupon proceeds to buy more bonds, or if you have a business that earns 12% on equity and retains all its earnings, both will grow at a comparable rate. In fact, in my example, both will end up with $300 million in capital by 2015 and earn over $32 million in the final year. It just goes to show that sometimes bonds and businesses aren't as different as you might think.
What was the yield on 20-year AAA tax-exempt bonds in 1946 and how did it compare to potential business investments at the time?

The yield on those bonds was slightly below 1%. To put that into perspective, it's like buying a business that can only earn 1% on its book value, which is a pretty dismal prospect. Meanwhile, you could have invested in businesses with great future prospects that were earning 10%, 12%, or 15% after tax on book value. It's a no-brainer - the bond investment just didn't make sense compared to the potential of those businesses.
What advice do you think investors should take away from your discussion of bond investment and business perspective?

I think investors should approach bond investment with a businessman's perspective, as I've said. It's essential to think about the potential returns and risks in the same way you would when evaluating a business opportunity. As Ben Graham so aptly put it in 'The Intelligent Investor', investment is most intelligent when it is most businesslike. So, investors should be cautious and not rush into bond investments that offer inadequate returns, just as they wouldn't invest in a business with poor prospects.
What do you think is the key characteristic of intelligent investing, according to Ben Graham's book 'The Intelligent Investor'

I think Ben Graham nailed it when he said that investment is most intelligent when it is most businesslike. That's the core idea - treating investments like a business decision, not just some speculative gamble.
Why do you think most managers are hesitant to make unconventional decisions, even if they might be intelligent ones?

Well, it's pretty simple: their personal gain-to-pain ratio is all out of whack. If an unconventional decision pays off, they get a pat on the back, but if it doesn't, they're out of a job. It's a lot safer for them to fail conventionally - after all, no individual lemming ever gets bad press, right?
Why do you and Charlie Munger behave unconventionally with Berkshire's investments?

We behave unconventionally because, as owners of 47% of Berkshire's stock, we don't have to worry about being fired. This freedom, combined with receiving our rewards as owners rather than managers, allows us to make decisions with Berkshire's money as we would with our own. It's a simple yet powerful mindset.
What's the reasoning behind concentrating investments in a few securities rather than diversifying more widely?

Our concentration strategy makes sense for us because of our exceptional financial strength. We can afford to own large blocks of a few securities that we've carefully selected and bought at attractive prices. As Billy Rose once said, having too many investments is like having a harem of forty women - you never get to know any of them very well. By focusing on a few key investments, we can really get to know them and make more informed decisions.
Why do you choose not to disclose your investment activities in securities to shareholders or the press?

I don't disclose our investment activities because the buying and selling of securities is a competitive business. If others know what we're doing, they might follow suit, which could drive up prices or reduce the amount we can buy. It's like trying to get a good deal on a car - if the salesman knows you're willing to pay top dollar, he's not going to give you a discount. We want to keep our actions private to avoid giving others an unfair advantage.
What is your general view on purchasing long-term bonds?

To be honest, I'm not a big fan of buying most long-term bonds under most circumstances. We've bought very few in recent years, and that's because we think they often don't offer the best value. Our WPPSS purchases were an exception, but overall, we're pretty selective when it comes to long-term bonds.
Why do you generally dislike the purchase of most long-term bonds?

I dislike long-term bonds because I view the long-term outlook for dollars as dismal, and I believe substantial inflation lies ahead. It's like lending someone money for 10 or 20 years without adjusting for the fact that the money they're paying you back with might be worth a lot less by then.
What happens to a diversified stock portfolio and bonds in the event of runaway inflation?

In the case of runaway inflation, a diversified stock portfolio would likely suffer a significant loss in real value, but bonds already outstanding would suffer even more. It's a grim scenario for both, but bonds would be particularly hard hit.
Why do you think an all-bond portfolio carries a 'wipe out' risk?

I think an all-bond portfolio carries a 'wipe out' risk because, in certain circumstances like high inflation, bonds already outstanding would suffer far more than a diversified stock portfolio. It's like trying to navigate a ship through treacherous waters without a life jacket - you're exposed to a lot of potential damage.
What kind of earnings cannot be distributed as dividends without harming the business?

I call them 'restricted' earnings. These are earnings that, due to inflation, are necessary for the business to maintain its economic position. If we distribute these earnings as dividends, the business would lose ground in areas like sales volume, competitive position, or financial strength. It's like trying to run a car without gas - it just won't go far.
What happens to a company that consistently distributes 'restricted' earnings as dividends?

If a company keeps paying out these restricted earnings, it's headed for trouble - it'll lose its edge in areas like sales, competitiveness, and financial stability. Unless it gets an infusion of new equity capital, it's destined for oblivion.
You mentioned Consolidated Edison as an example. What was unusual about their situation?

Well, Consolidated Edison was in a tough spot due to regulatory policies, and their stock was selling for as low as a quarter of its book value. The irony was that even though reinvesting earnings essentially turned dollars into quarters in terms of market value, they still chose to reinvest most of their earnings rather than paying them out to owners.
If interest rates are 5%, what should a rational investor do with their 10% bond coupon, and why?

If interest rates are 5%, I'd advise taking the coupon in additional bonds and then selling them. This way, you'd get more cash than if you took the coupon directly in cash. It's like getting a better deal on your money - why settle for less when you can have more?
What would you do with your 10% bond coupon if interest rates were 15%, and why?

With interest rates at 15%, I'd take my coupon in cash. Reinvesting it in 10% bonds wouldn't make sense since their market value would be far less than the cash I could get. If I still want 10% bonds, I can just buy them in the market at a discount - it's a smarter way to use my money.

Why do CEOs often instruct subsidiaries with lower expected earnings to distribute their earnings to subsidiaries with higher expected earnings, but fail to apply the same logic to the parent company's dividend policy?

I've seen this happen time and time again - CEOs will happily shuffle money around between subsidiaries to maximize returns, but when it comes to the parent company, they often stick to traditional dividend policies without giving it much thought. It's like they're wearing two different hats, and it just doesn't make sense.
How should shareholders evaluate whether managers should retain earnings, according to you?

Shareholders should be careful not to just look at the total earnings and capital of the company as a whole. They need to dig deeper and consider what's going on in the core business, especially during inflationary periods. If a company has a strong core business, it can generate a lot of excess cash, even with minimal incremental capital. So, shareholders should ask themselves - and management should be prepared to explain - why earnings are being retained, and whether it's really in the best interests of the owners.
What is the date and location of Berkshire's annual meeting, and what makes it different from other annual meetings?

Our annual meeting will be on May 21, 1985, in Omaha. I think what sets ours apart is the quality of the discussion - we get a wide variety of thoughtful questions about the business, and Charlie and I are happy to answer them all. It's a real forum for business discussion, not just a stage for theatrics or personal agendas.
Are there any limits to the questions you'll answer at the annual meeting?
Yes, there are some limits. We won't discuss business matters where candor might cost our company real money. Other than that, we're open to answering any questions our shareholders might have.
